content_list: The matters that may be so specified are matters which the Secretary of State considers that it would be desirable for secure tenants to have information about when considering whether to exercise the right to buy or the right to acquire on rent to mortgage terms.
Where the right to buy belongs to two or more persons jointly, the right to acquire on rent to mortgage terms also belongs to them jointly.

The right to buy cannot be exercised if the person, or one of the persons, to whom the right to buy belongsâ (a) has made a bankruptcy application that has not been determined or has a bankruptcy petition pending against him, (b) is an undischarged bankrupt, (c) has made a composition or arrangement with his creditors the terms of which remain to be fulfilled, or (d) is a person in relation to whom a moratorium period under a debt relief order applies (under Part 7A of the Insolvency Act 1986).
A secure tenant claims to exercise the right to buy by written notice to that effect served on the landlord.

Where by such a notice any members of the tenantâs family are validly required to share the right to buy with the tenant, the right to buy belongs to the tenant and those members jointly and he and they shall be treated for the purposes of this Part as joint tenants.

The right to buy does not arise unless the period which, in accordance with Schedule 4, is to be taken into account for the purposes of this section is at least three years.

Subject to the following provisions of this Part, a person exercising the right to buy is entitled to a discount of a percentage calculated by reference to the period which is to be taken into account in accordance with Schedule 4 (qualifying period for right to buy and discount).
